bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
Gaboon Nov. 26th 1866
Monsieur the Commandant Superior of the French settlements, West Coast of Africa
We the undersigned merchants established at Gaboon having been made acquirable with the circular which was addressed to us by your order on the 16th of this month, and in accordance with your invitation on the occasion of our visit to you on the 24th of September last on the subject of the circular dated the 21st of the smae month Have the honor to state to you that which follows.
The merchantile community of Gaboon was painfully impressed on learning by the announcement contained in your first circular that the other country having thought proper to evade the local expenses you should deem it necessary to make it support the amount of this contain commencing by causing no to pay for licenses, which or consider to be very high if compared to those paid in France when trade is so much more important than have.
That moreever when we established ourselves at Gaboon we were far from forcing that so sudden a change would one day come upon us and in a manners so burdensome in were so mad. the firtters from supposing it suing that the country is one of the protest and must son unhealthy of the Coast of Africa.
